Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(w) \\) which maps complex numbers under the transformation \\(z(w) = e^{iw}\\). We study its effects on waves modeled by the integral transformation \\(x(t) = \\int_{-\\pi}^{\\pi} z(w)e^{iwt} dw\\).

If we initially apply \\(z(w) = e^{iw}\\) to a wave function with a specific frequency domain, and allow the wave to propagate without any intervention, does \\(x(t)\\) at time T remain the same compared to direct computation at T without any transformations?
Explanation: The transformation by \\(z(w) = e^{iw}\\) essentially alters the phase of each frequency component. When calculating \\(x(t)\\) after the transformation, the phase shift introduced by \\(e^{iw}\\) results in a change of the waveform, affecting both amplitude and phase. This makes the wave at time T different from what would be obtained by just evolving the original wave without transformation.
